entity1.name: Memory formation
entity1.description: A stage in memory formation where information is transformed into a format that can be stored in the brain.;;;Interconnected groups of neurons in the brain that work together to process and transmit information.;;;The central organ of the nervous system, which is located in the skull and responsible for controlling most bodily activities.;;;A fundamental property of the nervous system that allows for changes in synaptic strength, which is crucial for learning and memory.;;;The central organ of the nervous system, which controls most bodily activities, thoughts, and sensations.;;;A process in which synaptic strength is increased over time, contributing to learning and memory formation.;;;The process by which the brain encodes, stores, and retrieves information.;;;A region in the brain's medial temporal lobe that plays a crucial role in the consolidation of information from short-term to long-term memory, and spatial navigation.;;;Physical changes in the brain that represent stored information.;;;The brain is the central organ of the nervous system, responsible for controlling and coordinating bodily functions and cognitive processes.;;;A process in the brain that involves encoding, storing, and retrieving information.;;;Mental operations involved in acquiring knowledge and understanding through thought, experience, and the senses.;;;The central organ of the nervous system, which controls most bodily activities, including movement, sensation, thought, and memory.;;;A complex and fascinating process that is essential for our daily functioning and overall well-being.;;;The junctions between nerve cells that allow the transmission of electrical or chemical signals.;;;The central organ of the nervous system that controls most bodily functions and processes information from the senses.;;;The mechanisms and activities of neurons that underlie cognitive functions such as memory formation.;;;The physiological processes and structures in the nervous system that underlie cognitive functions such as memory formation.;;;A cognitive process by which information is encoded, stored, and retrieved from the brain.;;;A phase of memory formation where memories are stabilized, making them more resistant to interference over time.;;;Interconnected groups of neurons that process and transmit information within the nervous system. They are fundamental to understanding brain function and learning processes.;;;The ability to perform mental tasks, including perception, memory, decision-making, and problem-solving.;;;A complex brain structure embedded in the temporal lobe of the cerebral cortex, involved in the consolidation of information from short-term memory to long-term memory.;;;The process by which new information is transferred from short-term memory to long-term memory, making it more stable and durable over time.;;;A small almond-shaped group of nuclei located deep within the temporal lobes of the brain, involved in processing emotions and memory.;;;The process by which the brain encodes, stores, and retrieves memories.;;;The central organ of the nervous system, responsible for processing sensory information and controlling bodily functions.;;;The basic functional units of the nervous system, responsible for transmitting information through electrical and chemical signals.;;;The process by which the brain encodes and stores information for later retrieval.;;;Tasks designed to assess or engage memory functions, often used in psychological and neurological research to understand how the brain processes and stores information.;;;The process by which the brain encodes, consolidates, and stores information for later retrieval.;;;A part of the brain involved in memory formation and storage.;;;A group of nuclei located deep within the temporal lobes of the brain, associated with processing emotions and forming memories of emotional events.;;;A complex brain structure embedded in the temporal lobe of the brain, involved in the consolidation of information from short-term memory to long-term memory.;;;The process by which the brain creates and stores new memories.;;;Memory consolidation is a process by which new information is transferred from short-term to long-term memory, making it more stable and durable over time.;;;A region in the brain located at the base of the skull, involved in motor control and some cognitive functions such as attention and language.;;;Mental representations of past experiences that can be recalled or reconstructed by the brain.;;;A set of brain structures that support a variety of functions including emotion, behavior, motivation, and long-term memory.

entity6.name: sensory information
entity6.description: Data received through the senses, such as sight, sound, touch, taste, and smell.

entity8.name: sight
entity8.description: The ability to perceive the visible world through the eyes.

entity9.name: sound
entity9.description: The ability to perceive auditory information through the ears.

entity10.name: touch
entity10.description: The ability to perceive physical contact and pressure on the skin.

entity11.name: taste
entity11.description: The ability to perceive flavors through the tongue and mouth.

entity12.name: smell
entity12.description: The ability to perceive odors through the nose.

entity15.name: prefrontal cortex
entity15.description: The anterior part of the frontal lobes of the brain, involved in planning complex cognitive behavior, personality expression, decision making, and moderating social behavior.

entity23.name: episodic memories
entity23.description: A type of long-term memory that involves the recall of specific events and experiences.

entity25.name: procedural memories
entity25.description: A type of implicit memory that involves skills and habits, often learned through repetition and practice.

entity27.name: motor cortex
entity27.description: An area of the cerebral cortex that is responsible for controlling voluntary muscle movements.

entity30.name: Retrieval
entity30.description: A cognitive process that involves the activation of neural networks to reconstruct memories from stored traces.

entity37.name: neocortex
entity37.description: The outer layer of the cerebrum, responsible for higher-order functions such as sensory perception, spatial reasoning, conscious thought, and language.

entity40.name: neuroimaging techniques
entity40.description: A type of neuroimaging that measures brain activity by detecting changes in blood flow. It is used to map neural activity and understand the functional organization of the brain.;;;A set of methods used to create images of the brain and other parts of the nervous system, often for research or diagnostic purposes.

entity42.name: electroencephalography (EEG)
entity42.description: A method for recording electrical activity in the brain using electrodes placed on the scalp. It is used to study brain function and diagnose conditions such as epilepsy.

entity45.name: emotion
entity45.description: A mental state that is characterized by feelings, physiological responses, and expressions.

entity46.name: attention
entity46.description: The ability to focus on specific stimuli or tasks while ignoring others.

entity47.name: sleep
entity47.description: A naturally recurring state characterized by reduced or absent consciousness, relatively suspended sensory activity, and inactivity of nearly all voluntary muscles.;;;A naturally recurring state of rest characterized by altered consciousness, relatively inhibited sensory activity, and reduced muscle activity.
entity47.chunkid: The Science Behind Memory Formation21;;;The Science Behind Memory Formation24

entity58.name: learning
entity58.description: The acquisition of knowledge or skills through study, experience, or teaching.

entity59.name: memory disorders
entity59.description: Conditions that affect the ability to form, retain, or recall memories, often due to brain damage or disease.
